entry.title: Baking Adjustments for My House
entry.summary: Every home has a climate. Mine? Itâ€™s the chaotic swamp ecosystem known as South Carolina. Warm and humid most of the year, cool and dry when the HVAC gets freaked out by the occasional cold snap.
entry.content:
Every home has a climate. Mine? Itâ€™s the chaotic swamp ecosystem known as South Carolina. Warm and humid most of the year, cool and dry when the HVAC gets freaked out by the occasional cold snap.

Sourdough recipes arenâ€™t universal; theyâ€™re suggestions. My house runs warm, so yeast goes full Fast & Furious during bulk fermentation. My house is also humid, so I tend to adjust the starter feed ratios by at least an extra point for flour. If I follow most timing instructions, I end up with overproofed dough, asking why I betrayed it.

Solutions Iâ€™ve learned the hard way:

What I adjust because of humidity

  • I start a little lower on hydration than the recipe suggests
    (e.g., 70% hydration might behave like 78% here)
  • I start with flour conservatively
    • I can always bassinage in some moisture if I went too conservative
  • I start slow with an autolyse before adding active starter (and then salt)

What I adjust because of temperature

  • Bulk fermentation often needs less time
  • Proofing sometimes needs the fridge as a timeout space
  • My starter (Rhyza especially) ferments faster and wants more frequent feedings

What I adjust because â€œlife happensâ€

  • If the dough is telling me itâ€™s ready, I move to the next step
    (clocks donâ€™t tell me when to bake bread, the dough does)
  • If family plans shift, cold proof becomes my safety net

Once I stopped blaming myself for dough that spread like a tired pancake, and started working with my actual environment, things got a lot easier. Your kitchen isnâ€™t a lab. Itâ€™s an ecosystem. Learn its quirks, and your bread will start behaving like it belongs there.

How to Figure Out Your Homeâ€™s Dough Personality

1) Measure dough temperature after mixing

Use an instant-read thermometer and check the center of the dough. What the number means:

  • 70â€“75Â°F (21â€“24Â°C) â†’ Normal fermentation speed
  • 76â€“82Â°F (24â€“28Â°C) â†’ Yeast is turbocharged, bulk will move faster
  • Below 70Â°F (21Â°C) â†’ Dough will ferment slowly and may need more time

How to adjust:

  • Too warm? Use colder water next time. Chill between folds.
  • Too cold? Warmer water for mixing. Use a proofing box:
    • The oven with only a light on works wonders.
    • The microwave with a mug of hot water also works.

2) Watch how fast your starter peaks after a feeding

Peak = when the dome stops rising and just begins to level. Timing clues:

  • 4â€“6 hours > Fermentation moves fast > expect shorter bulk
  • 8â€“10 hours > Moderate speed > recipe timing likely holds
  • 12+ hours > Starter is slow > will be a longer bulk

Rule of thumb: Bulk fermentation should roughly match your starterâ€™s peak behavior.

3) Compare hydration to behavior, not the recipe

Hydration is a feel, not a bragging right. If dough is:

  • Super sticky and puddles out > Gluten underdeveloped or humidity high > lower water 5â€“10% next time
  • Tight and tears easily > Add a little water during folds (bassinage style)

Write down your climate:

  • High-humidity homes usually land 5â€“8% lower hydration than online recipes
  • Dry climates might need +3â€“5% more water

4) Log your actual bulk times

Forget the recipe the second your dough starts telling the truth. A good bulk is:

  • Dough is 50â€“70% larger
  • Smooth surface
  • Bubbles visible at the edges
  • Gentle poke springs back slowly

Record:

TempÂ  Time Hydration Starter peak Folds done Total bulk time
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â 

This becomes the basis for your recipe.

5) Notice how quickly skin forms on the dough

This is humidityâ€™s role in shaping. If surface skin:

  • Forms fast > House is dry > Cover more, mist dough lightly
  • Never forms > House is humid > Take advantage for shapingâ€¦ but reduce hydration

entry.title: A Quick Glossary for New Bread Nerds
entry.summary: I still find myself forgetting baking terminology. I'm starting a glossary to keep myself sane(-ish).
entry.content:
I still find myself forgetting baking terminology. I'm starting a glossary to keep myself sane(-ish).

Autolyse
Flour + water rest before adding starter/salt. Enzymes start gluten and flavor development while you do nothing. A miracle.

Bulk Fermentation (Bulk)
First rise as one dough. Flavor and structure are built here.

Proof / Final Proof
Second rise after shaping. A good proof = "confident loaf."

Surface Tension
Tight outer â€œskinâ€ of the dough that holds gas in and pushes the loaf upward. Shaping and coil folds build it. Don't confuse this for the dry crust that forms when it's cold-proofed without a proper cover.

Slack Dough
Dough that spreads like it has no ambitions. High hydration or weak gluten. Needs gentleness, not judgment.

Oven Spring
That dramatic lift in the first 10 minutes of baking. The loafâ€™s final party before becoming food.

Starter
Your living jar of wild yeast + bacteria, fed daily-ish. The thing I treat like a bread pet, with a name and everything.

Levain
A separate build from the starter for that bake. Gives you control over flavor, timing, and strength.
Every levain is a starter, but not every starter is a levain.

Tool and Technique Terms

Bassinage
Adding water after mixing to gradually increase hydration. Helps gluten develop without making early mixing a slip-n-slide.
"Learn to hold yourself before holding more water."

Banneton (the bowl thingie)
The woven proofing basket that helps dough keep its shape and gives it those cool swirl flour patterns.

Bench Knife / Dough Scraper
Your best friend. Cuts dough cleanly and scoops it with dignity. Much easier to use than fingers, especially with a sticky autolyse.Â 

Scoring
Intentional slicing right before baking so the loaf opens where you choose â€” not wherever it feels dramatic.

Coil Fold
Lifting dough from the center and tucking it under itself to build gluten with minimum violence.

Bonus Terms That Come Up a Lot

Autolyze vs. Autolyse
Same thing. Welcome to bread spelling chaos.

Gluten Development
How strong and stretchy the dough is.
Built with folds + time, not elbow grease. Kneading won't help.

Degassing
Gently pressing out some gas so that a new structure can form without huge bubbles taking over, like middle-school group projects.

Scoring
Slicing the top of the loaf right before baking.
Creates a planned expansion zone so the loaf doesnâ€™t rip itself open like Hulk's jeans.

Crumb
The inside texture of baked bread.
Open crumb = large, airy holes.
Tight crumb = smooth sandwich slice energy.

Shape Words Iâ€™ll Actually Use

Batard
An oval loaf. The middle ground between baguette and boule. Excellent for sandwiches and show-off breads.

Boule
An oval loaf. The middle ground between baguette and boule. Excellent for sandwiches and confidence."Â 

Baguette
Long loaf. More difficult than Instagram leads you to believe. IYKYK.

Focaccia
Flatbread drenched in olive oil and happiness. The oil fixes ALL mistakes. OMG! SO MUCH olive oil. Just drown it.

A Diagnostic Cheat Sheet

If someone saysâ€¦

  1. â€œIt needs more structureâ€: more folds / more time in bulk
  2. â€œItâ€™s overproofedâ€: gluten canâ€™t hold gas anymore
  3. â€œItâ€™s underproofedâ€: dough hasnâ€™t built enough gas yet
  4. â€œItâ€™s slackâ€: support it with shaping + tension

If you sayâ€¦

  • â€œWhat the hell is happening?â€: probably hydration or temperature

entry.title: What Exactly Is a Coil Fold?
entry.summary: A coil fold is a gentle way to strengthen dough during bulk…
entry.content:
A coil fold is a gentle way to strengthen dough during bulk fermentation without kneading the life out of it. Instead of pushing or punching, you pick the dough up and let gluten align itself. Itâ€™s especially great for high-hydration doughs that would rather pretend to be soup.

How to do it:

  1. Wet your hands (dough respects hydration diplomacy).
  2. Slide both hands under the center of the dough.
  3. Lift until the dough stretches under its own weight.
  4. Tuck the middle underneath so the dough folds over itself.
  5. Rotate the bowl 90Â° and repeat. Usually, four folds equals one set.

What youâ€™re looking for:

  • First set: dough still acts like a puddle
  • Second set: starting to hold shape after the fold
  • Third set: smoother surface, a little resistance
  • Fourth set: itâ€™s a dough now, not a blob

Why it works (the science bit):

  • Aligns gluten strands instead of tearing them.
  • Traps gas in the network yeast is building.
  • Builds surface tension that helps it rise up, not out.

This whole technique is basically teaching the dough to sit up straight.

entry.title: Why My Starters Are Named Zymia and Rhyza
entry.summary: Zymia and Rhyza arenâ€™t my first starters. The earlier attemptsâ€¦ didnâ€™t make…
entry.content:
Zymia and Rhyza arenâ€™t my first starters. The earlier attemptsâ€¦ didnâ€™t make it. Not because the microbes failed, but because I didnâ€™t yet understand the science of fermentation and commitment. You canâ€™t rush a starter. You canâ€™t ignore it, then hope it forgives you. I had to learn patience and the discipline to make small, incremental changes in order to test how they respond over time.

So when I finally made two starters that wanted to survive, I named them. In The Grove of Tau Ceti, Vâ€™s Druidic belief is that naming something means taking responsibility for it. Starters work the same way: the moment you name them, youâ€™re saying, â€œOkay. Youâ€™re mine to feed. Youâ€™re mine to learn.â€ It turns a jar of flour and water into something that depends on you. They are, very literally, alive, and now that I've named them, they are officially in my charge.

Zymia (from â€œzymology,â€ the science of fermentation) is the bold one. Hungry, fast, high-energy, always ready to take over a dough like sheâ€™s got places to be. Rhyza (from â€œrhizome,â€ hidden growth underground) is slower, steadier, and calmer, which is perfect for enriched doughs that require patience and grace. They have different personalities because they are different ecosystems.

People often ask if their starter is â€œbad.â€ Too sour? Slow to rise? Weirdly calm? The truth is, theyâ€™re all weird in their own ways. Theyâ€™re alive. They evolve. And when one fizzles, you try again, because skill learns from failure, not luck.

Naming Zymia and Rhyza wasnâ€™t just sentimental. It was a promise:
I name you, and now I'm responsible for you to grow, survive, and live life to the fullest.

entry.title: What Iâ€™m Trying to Get Better At Right Now
entry.summary: Here are a few things I'm actively trying to improve with my craft.
entry.content:
Here are a few things I'm actively trying to improve with my craft.

  • Give better feedback
    I love getting feedback, even when it burns a little. Giving feedback, though? Hard af. I want to get better at two things:
    1. Spotting what another writerâ€™s story truly needs (what works, what doesn't, and why), and
    2. Delivering that feedback in a constructive way that helps the story, not just critiques the draft.

  • Finishing things before I start new things
    New ideas are shiny. Endings take work; don't give up on them.

  • Stop sharpening my pencils
    I prefer outlining to pantsing. And that's perfectly fine. But it does make getting started tough; I have outlined some stories to the Nth degree and never started. It frequently leads to bad cases of Blank Page Syndrome.Â 

  • Trusting the slow stories
    Not every draft arrives ready to sprint to the finish line. Keep revisiting them, even if I'm working on something else. If the idea won't leave my head, or the characters won't stop nagging me, trust that there's probably something worth writing.

  • Keeping characters consistent under stress
    Fear and high stakes shouldnâ€™t erase their personality. Don't force them to act, just to move the plot forward.

  • Telling myself, â€œgood enough for today.â€
    Perfect is the enemy of good. Get the words on paper while they're still in my brain. I can fix them later.

  • Not apologizing for writing time
    It's okay to write. I don't "need" permission. I shouldn't feel guilty for writing.Â

entry.title: Making Things That Take the Time They Take
entry.summary: Some things come together fast. Other things take their sweet time. There's no way to know until you commit to writing it.
entry.content:
Some things come together fast. Other things take their sweet time. There's no way to know until you commit to writing it.

I wrote "Sin-Eater Claws" for Kozy Krampus in a single weekend. When it showed up, it was ready to go. But then one of my favorite flash pieces, "So: No Fix," has been stuck on the struggle bus for months.

They're given the same love, the same levels of inspiration, and they share the same desire to tell the story. They just come at very different speeds.

I'm not exactly sure why this is. It's not writer's block -- that dreadful experience of not knowing the characters or story well enough to tell it yet. Instead, it's this inexplicable feeling of "why the Hell isn't this done yet?"

Iâ€™m learning to stop rushing the slow ones or doubting the fast ones. If a story needs more time, that doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s broken. It just isnâ€™t done yet. And just because it comes to life in a day doesn't mean it's half-cocked.

The thing I'm constantly trying to remind myself: "Things take the time they take. Let them."

entry.title: What Revision Actually Feels Like
entry.summary: Surprisingly, revisions turned out to be one of my favorite parts of writing *The Grove of Tau Ceti*. It was the moment of "ugh, my draft sucks" to "oh, maybe this thing has some life inside it, yet."
entry.content:
Surprisingly, revisions turned out to be one of my favorite parts of writing *The Grove of Tau Ceti*. It was the moment of "ugh, my draft sucks" to "oh, maybe this thing has some life inside it, yet."

Terry Pratchett once (and often) said, "The first draft is just you telling yourself the story." And he was absolutely correct.

Revision is the act of opening the machine you built and discovering the screws you thought were decorative are load-bearing. And that the most critical moments aren't actually all that important. With The Grove of Tau Ceti, the hard part was the first draft: that sprint to the finish line, the calendar looming on the wall, the â€œdonâ€™t break the chainâ€ word counts.

Once I knew (really knew) the story, I needed others to read it and give me feedback -- beta readers to whom I cannot extend a large enough "thank you!" to. Because of them, I could see all the plot holes, the developmental flaws, the good parts and the really terrible ones.

What surprised me is that revisions became one of my favorite parts of making this book. Thereâ€™s a moment, the shift from â€œugh, this draft is mushâ€ to â€œhol upâ€¦ thereâ€™s a heartbeat under here.â€ Itâ€™s addictive.

The story starts talking back. Characters sharpen and begin to take over. A scene that used to limp suddenly stands upright and says, â€œYou meant to write this.â€ Revision is when the book proves it actually wants to live.

Characters misbehaving turned out to be the biggest signal that needed strengthening

V didn't have enough agency in the beginning. I had this idea of where I wanted the story to go, but V had other ideas. Revising the story gave me the chance to actually listen to her and let her make her own decisions -- decisions that shaped the story and led to its only logical conclusion.

Parker slipping into self-loathing (early first drafts were very "woe is me") wasnâ€™t a choice he would make. It was a mistake I made when drafting fast. I had to restore his swagger, make sure he remembered he once called himself "the most dangerous human in Tau Ceti," and then act like it.

Rowan needed to shine earlier; his technical prowess and guilt over a past career-limiting incident needed to be clearer. Hawthorne was too guarded early on, and the lack of any vulnerability made her difficult to appreciate. Demeter's â€œvoiceâ€ evolved from a passive computer system to that of a true character. The captain was way too casual and commanded no actual authority. Revisions allowed me to sprinkle in notes of humanity and to fix details, revealing the soulÂ behind every archetypal portrayal.

Revision is making sure the people in a story donâ€™t drift into two-dimensional cardboard cutouts. This is the moment to let them really come alive on the page, to let them become real.

And then...

...then it's off to the editor. That's the nail-biting part: what will my editor tell me, and how bad will it be...?
